Award.AwardTitle: New, GK-12: Ingenuity Incubators Develop NSF Fellow Potential and Prepare Tech Students for Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF GK-12 Proposal # 0947869

PI - Doug Cooper ? University of Connecticut

Abstract: Ingenuity Incubators Prepare Technical High School Students for College Engineering

Through collaboration with teachers and students in the Connecticut Technical High School (Tech) System, NSF-funded PhD Fellows will obtain new perspectives on innovative research in sustainable engineering. By working with Tech School students in the classroom, the NSF Fellows will be challenged to expand their collaborative, leadership, teaching and communication skills. They will participate in training and educational activities that will nurture a thoughtful interest in K-12 education. They will seek to elevate the interest and preparedness of Tech School students for their transition into college science or engineering studies, and further develop and enrich the STEM instructional proficiency of Tech School teachers. In this project, NSF Fellows will work in Tech Schools to integrate their novel research in sustainable engineering into a creative innovation project-based classroom curriculum. Specifically, they will mentor pioneering Ingenuity Incubators, which are supplementary activities designed to enhance creativity, knowledge acquisition, leadership and communication skills. Emphasis will be placed on recruitment of NSF Fellows from underrepresented groups. Many Tech Schools are located in economically-depressed regions of Connecticut and enroll significant under-represented minority and women populations. This project will thus have a positive impact on educational engagement and diversity. The innovative programs of this work will strengthen the basic research and GK-12 instructional methods and training activities to the benefit of educational systems in Connecticut. Through systematic dissemination of results, this project will ultimately benefit GK-12 best-practices across the nation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Graduate K-12 (GK12) program was established in March of 2010 at the University of Connecticut (UConn).  Through this program STEM graduate students are integrated into classroom curriculum at K-12 schools to improve their skills, and to elevate interest and preparedness of technical high school students for college level STEM programs.  Furthermore, the GK12 program aims to enrich STEM instructional proficiency in technical high school teachers and instill a thoughtful interest in K-12 education in UConn faculty.  Nine technical schools throughout Connecticut participated in GK-12 program, along with the Connecticut Science Center and the Academy of Engineering and Green Technology.

Over the six program years, 29 graduate students participated in the GK-12 program.  The majority of students served as GK-12 Fellows for at least two years. All Fellows across all cohorts were directly involved in in-school activities with K-12 students, including leading small group activities and discussions, and presenting lessons and lectures to students.  Beyond the in-school activities, Fellows reported they participated in a wide range of activities sponsored by UConn’s GK12 program including professional development workshops and training, a summer orientation workshop, and a summer institute on STEM instruction.

Fellows indicated that participation in the program increased numerous aspects of their teaching skills, including their ability to teach STEM concepts and methods, explain STEM research and concepts to the non-technical audiences, as well as their ability to generate interest and develop instructional materials in STEM.  Moreover, Fellows developed skills and abilities that will be useful regardless of their career path post-graduation.

Participating in the GK-12 program was influential on Fellows.  Over two-thirds of Fellows find they are more interested in influencing public policy related to STEM and in working with K-12 teachers / students on STEM content and research.  Over half of Fellows expressed a greater interest in teaching since participating in the GK-12 program. 

On top of interacting with a fellow, K-12 teachers were also provided other GK-12 related activities to participate in, including workshops, training, and research opportunities.  When asked why they participated in the GK-12 program, they answered that they saw it as a way to help their own K-12 students. 

Nearly all teachers stated increased use of hands on / laboratory activities, variety of topics, in-depth concepts, and dialogue to enhance STEM learning and are more likely to incorporate current STEM research and technology in their teaching, as well as have students work on STEM investigations where they do not know the outcomes in advance. 

Over all program years, all Faculty Advisors thought the GK12 program helped the fellow improve their teamwork and teaching skills, gave them a benefit in the job market, and encouraged them to consider teaching further whether undergraduates or K-12.  

Survey findings indicate that the program was implemented as planned, with Fellows, Faculty Mentors and K-12 Teachers engaging in a broad range of activities supported by the program.

Through this program STEM graduate students are integrated into classroom curriculum at K-12 schools to improve their skills, and to elevate interest and preparedness of technical high school students for college level STEM programs. Furthermore, the GK12 program aims to enrich STEM instructional proficiency in technical high school teachers and instill a thoughtful interest in K-12 education in UConn faculty. Nine technical schools throughout Connecticut participated in GK-12 program, along with the Connecticut Science Center and the Academy of Engineering and Green Technology. Over the six program years, 29 graduate students participated in the GK-12 program. The majority of students served as GK-12 Fellows for at least two years. All Fellows across all cohorts were directly involved in in-school activities with K-12 students, including leading small group activities and discussions, and presenting lessons and lectures to students. Beyond the in-school activities, Fellows reported they participated in a wide range of activities sponsored by UConn?s GK12 program including professional development workshops and training, a summer orientation workshop, and a summer institute on STEM instruction. Fellows indicated that participation in the program increased numerous aspects of their teaching skills, including their ability to teach STEM concepts and methods, explain STEM research and concepts to the non-technical audiences, as well as their ability to generate interest and develop instructional materials in STEM. Over half of Fellows expressed a greater interest in teaching since participating in the GK-12 program. On top of interacting with a fellow, K-12 teachers were also provided other GK-12 related activities to participate in, including workshops, training, and research opportunities. When asked why they participated in the GK-12 program, they answered that they saw it as a way to help their own K-12 students. Nearly all teachers stated increased use of hands on / laboratory activities, variety of topics, in-depth concepts, and dialogue to enhance STEM learning and are more likely to incorporate current STEM research and technology in their teaching, as well as have students work on STEM investigations where they do not know the outcomes in advance. Over all program years, all Faculty Advisors thought the GK12 program helped the fellow improve their teamwork and teaching skills, gave them a benefit in the job market, and encouraged them to consider teaching further whether undergraduates or K-12. Survey findings indicate that the program was implemented as planned, with Fellows, Faculty Mentors and K-12 Teachers engaging in a broad range of activities supported by the program.
